item.title: Representative Eric Swalwell Will Run for California Governor
item.description: Representative Eric Swalwell, a Democrat, is likely to emphasize his history of fighting President Trump, an approach that many Democratic voters say they want their elected officials to take.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Eric Swalwell is the latest Democrat to announce he will run for California governor.

item.title: Justice Dept. Sues California Over College Benefits for Undocumented Students
item.description: The lawsuit is the third filed by the Justice Department against the state in a week.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: The University of California, Los Angeles, campus.

item.title: Pras Michel of the Fugees Gets 14 Years for Illegal Foreign Influence Scheme
item.description: Mr. Michel was convicted in April 2023 of 10 criminal counts, including money laundering, illegal lobbying and witness tampering.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Kevin Lamarque/Reuters
item.media:description: Pras Michel outside the federal courthouse in Washington during his trial in 2023.

item.title: Qaeda Convict Returns to Guantánamo Court 17 Years After Trial
item.description: The Yemeni prisoner spent nearly seven hours at the war court, displaying some of the defiance of his 2008 proceeding.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned prison camp at Guantánamo Bay. Ali Hamza al-Bahlul, who was sentenced to life in 2008, appeared at the base war court on Thursday in a proceeding concerning the upcoming capital trial of another prisoner.

item.title: Judge Concludes Prosecutors Can Circumvent Federal Grand Juries in D.C.
item.description: The ruling by a federal judge found that federal prosecutors could fall back on local grand juries to approve serious charges when they failed to persuade a federal grand jury.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Saul Loeb/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The decision by Chief Judge James E. Boasberg of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia applied immediately only to Kevontae Stewart, a Washington resident.

item.title: Coast Guard Says Swastika and Noose Displays Are No Longer Hate Incidents
item.description: A new servicewide policy recasts swastikas and nooses as “politically divisive,” revises harassment provisions and deletes protections for transgender troops.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Minho Kim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of the Coast Guard patrolling the waterways near President Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida.

item.title: Missouri Judge Who Wore Elvis Wig in Court Agrees to Resign
item.description: Judge Matthew E.P. Thornhill also talked about politics and played Elvis songs in court, a judicial commission said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: St. Charles County Circuit Court
item.media:description: “Elvis was a super talent,” Matthew E.P. Thornhill, a circuit judge in St. Charles County, Mo., said last year in a local television interview. “If I just had Elvis’s hair, I’d be unstoppable.”

item.title: Judge Temporarily Blocks Trump From Deploying National Guard in D.C.
item.description: Judge Jia M. Cobb found that the presence of more than 2,000 National Guard troops, many from outside D.C., was most likely unlawful. She paused the order from taking effect until Dec. 11.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.category: US Federal Takeover of Metropolitan Police Dept (DC)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: National Guard members in Washington in August.

item.title: Short on Cash, D.N.C. Took Out $15 Million Loan in October
item.description: The move, unusual for a year without a midterm or presidential election, is the latest sign of financial distress for the Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
item.media:description: Ken Martin, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, at a rally this month in Newark for Representative Mikie Sherrill, who was elected New Jersey’s next governor.

item.title: The F.C.C. chair questioned the BBC over edits to a Trump speech.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brendan Carr, the chair of the Federal Communications Commission, in Washington in February.

item.title: Trump Calls Democrats’ Military Video ‘Seditious Behavior, Punishable by Death’
item.description: President Trump was reacting to a video that reminded members of the military that they are not supposed to obey illegal orders.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has flexed his power over the military during his second term and his attempts to politicize the armed forces have become more overt.

item.title: Justice Dept. Appears to Be Examining Potential Leaks in Schiff Inquiry
item.description: A subpoena issued by the F.B.I. suggests the Justice Department may be seeking to identify officials who might have shared information about the inquiry into Senator Adam Schiff in an unauthorized way.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Mark Schiefelbein/Associated Press; Craig Hudson for The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Justice Department appears interested in the interactions among Bill Pulte, Ed Martin and the “key witness” in the mortgage fraud investigation of Senator Adam Schiff.

item.title: Appeals Court Blocks Release of Hundreds of Chicago-Area Immigration Detainees
item.description: The order temporarily halts a federal judge’s call to release several hundred people arrested during the Trump administration’s immigration crackdown in Illinois.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Border Patrol agents arrested a man in Chicago in October.

item.title: U.S. Ran a War Game on Ousting Maduro. Venezuela Fell Into Chaos.
item.description: An official U.S. government exercise during President Trump’s first term forecast turmoil and potential violence in a post-Maduro Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a group loyal to President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, during a rally in Caracas in September.

item.title: Congressional Republicans Begin to Look Beyond Trump
item.description: Election defeats earlier this month and the approach of 2026 have G.O.P. lawmakers cautiously asserting themselves.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Officials Move to Drop Case Against Drivers in Chicago Immigration Clash
item.description: Two motorists had been charged with crimes in connection to an incident in Chicago in October. Federal authorities had shot and injured one of the drivers.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal law enforcement officers in Chicago’s Brighton Park neighborhood in October.

item.title: Homeland Security Says Border Patrol Operation in Charlotte Is Not Over
item.description: The mayor and sheriff said earlier in the day that the operation appeared to have concluded. But a homeland security spokeswoman said that the effort was “not ending anytime soon.”
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Matt Kelley/Associated Press
item.media:description: U.S. Border Patrol agents in Charlotte, N.C., on Monday.

item.title: Senate Democrats Investigate Kennedy Center Deals With Trump Allies
item.description: Under Richard Grenell, the performing arts center has given steep discounts to CPAC and FIFA, signed contracts with administration associates and spent lavishly on friends.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Richard Grenell at a White House dinner for the Kennedy Center board in May. Since he was tapped to lead the center, it has become something resembling a private club for the president’s friends and supporters.

item.title: Democrats Raise Concerns Over Allied Curbs on Intelligence Sharing
item.description: Britain’s limits on sharing information reflect growing unease among partner nations over the legality of the U.S. strikes on boats purportedly carrying drugs.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Jim Himes of Connecticut, the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, said the loss of intelligence from Colombia could have real effects.

item.title: Before Fatal UPS Plane Crash, Engine Brace Had Cracked, Safety Agency Says
item.description: The cargo plane was taking off from Louisville earlier this month when it crashed moments after becoming airborne, killing the three crew members and 11 people on the ground.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry/Associated Press
item.media:description: Smoke rising above the UPS cargo plane crash site near Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport on Nov. 4.

item.title: MacKenzie Scott Expands Giving Spree to Tribal Colleges
item.description: The billionaire philanthropist is steering millions of dollars toward tribal schools, after the Trump administration proposed a significant federal funding cut.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: KC McGinnis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Little Priest Tribal College in Winnebago, Neb., announced Thursday that Ms. Scott had given it $5 million.

item.title: Lawsuit Challenges Trump Administration Over $1.8 Million in Immigration Fines
item.description: A class-action suit accuses the Trump administration of weaponizing civil penalties to force undocumented migrants to self-deport through enormous penalties.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents conducting a street raid in New York last month. Some migrants have been assessed a $1,000 daily fine for being illegally present in the United States.

item.title: Trump and Vance Were Not Invited to Dick Cheney’s Funeral
item.description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney, a once-powerful Republican, turned on Mr. Trump last year by announcing he would vote for Vice President Kamala Harris.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney, who died earlier this month, said in 2024 he would not support his party’s presidential nominee, Donald J. Trump, and would instead vote for Vice President Kamala Harris.

item.title: Wyden Presses for Investigation Into JPMorgan Chase and Epstein
item.description: Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, wants to examine how the nation’s largest bank handled the reporting of more than $1 billion in suspicious transactions.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, at the Capitol in June.

item.title: Epstein Emails Add to Former Harvard President Larry Summers’s Controversies
item.description: The former Harvard president has come back from controversy before, but revelations in new Epstein emails are threatening his omnipresence in public life.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lawrence H. Summers resigned from the Harvard presidency decades ago after he was criticized over statements about women. But he remained a powerful public figure.

item.title: Cheney Remembered for Transforming National Security and Standing Against Trump
item.description: As the former vice president was honored at Washington National Cathedral on Thursday, many eyes were focused on who came — and who did not.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Aaron Schwartz for The New York Times

item.title: Tennessee House Race Rivets Democrats and Worries Republicans
item.description: Still the favorites, Republicans have grown nervous about a House special election that could show whether the political environment continues to shift leftward.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Aftyn Behn, a Democrat, is facing off against Matt Van Epps, a Republican, in a House special election for a district in Tennessee that President Trump won by more than 22 percentage points last year.

item.title: Arrest Is Made in 1991 Texas Murder After Students Step In
item.description: Criminology students from the University of Texas at Arlington re-examined the case of Cynthia Gonzalez, whose body was found south of Fort Worth. Their work led to an arrest this month.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Arlington Police Department
item.media:description: An arrest this month in the September 1991 murder of Cynthia Gonzalez, 25, came after the students in a criminology class at the University of Texas at Arlington re-examined the evidence in the case.

item.title: Miss Hall’s Students Accused a Teacher of Sexual Abuse, But Prosecutors Won’t Charge Him
item.description: Despite evidence of sexual abuse by a Massachusetts teacher, prosecutors said no criminal conduct occurred. Now survivors are trying to change consent laws they say “offered cover” to their abuser.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell and Shaila Dewan
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administrators at Miss Hall’s School in Pittsfield, Mass., apologized to students and alumnae for sexual misconduct by teachers and staff members that was documented in an investigative report.

item.title: Howard Lutnick’s Family Business Is Cashing In on Data Center Deals
item.description: The commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick, is involved in A.I. data center deals that overlap with work his family is doing. Our investigative reporter Eric Lipton describes what we know about these deals for massive data center projects, one of which includes a planned nuclear power plant to be named after President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton, Christina Shaman, June Kim, Zach Wood and Leila Medina

item.title: Family Affair: Commerce Secretary’s Sons Cash In on A.I. Frenzy
item.description: Howard Lutnick is helping push data center projects. His family companies are profiting from them.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton, Michael Rothfeld, David Yaffe-Bellany and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mammoth data center is rising in Amarillo, Texas. Firms controlled by the Lutnick family have helped finance it, banking millions in fees in the process.

item.title: Catholic Group Sues Trump Administration for Access to Immigration Facility
item.description: The Coalition for Spiritual and Public Leadership says its members have been blocked from ministering at an ICE detention center near Chicago.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Adam Gray/Associated Press
item.media:description: People marching to the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Broadview, Ill., in October.

item.title: Dead Sperm Whale on Nantucket Is Too Big to Move, for Now
item.description: A local nonprofit said the 52-ton mammal is “far too big, awkward and heavy to remove.” A town official later said it could be dragged out to sea by Thanksgiving.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
